text:
DANA BASH: In many
homes, Sunday dinners
aren't just about the food.

They're about families
spending time together.

And two senators
we caught up with

believe breaking bread can
be used for a lot more.

Can the racial divide
be bridged with a meal?

- Can we get another
cornbread as well?

DANA BASH: That's the simple
idea behind Solution Sundays,

an initiative started
by two senators,

Tim Scott of South Carolina
and Jim Lankford from Oklahoma.

JAMES LANKFORD: I just started
asking people that I ran into,

have you ever had a person
of another race in your home
for dinner?

And I had very few people
that can answer yes.

DANA BASH: Have you experienced
the issue, either maybe

with yourself or with
your constituents,

African-Americans that
just have never had
a white person in their house?

TIM SCOTT: And vice versa
as often as anything else.

For me, it's hard to
hate what you know.
And it's just so simple.

DANA BASH: So these
Republicans issued a challenge
to their constituents.

Invite a family of different
race over for a Sunday meal.

JAMES LANKFORD: What
they're continually telling

me is a sense of joy and
relief and a transition

that they personally
experience something
around the dinner table.
DANA BASH: It's almost--

maybe this is too
strong, but sort
of self-imposed segregation.
TIM SCOTT: Absolutely.

And the funny thing
is, for me, it's

surprising how many
people come back
and say, they're just like me.
What did you expect?

DANA BASH: We took a break
from Washington's divisiveness

to replicate a typical Solution
Sunday at Kenny's Barbecue

with a group of local religious
and community leaders.

- Must be something about
relationships that are built
around eating, around food.

And we have just
desegregated that.

SAMUEL RODRIGUEZ:
But it requires
us to do this right now.

I mean, it's like, I
have to look at you.

BARRY BLACK: Step outside
of your comfort zone,

and invite someone
into your circle.

DANA BASH: For Scott,
a black Republican

from the south, his own
unique circumstances
have paved the way.
You, by definition, are--

TIM SCOTT: A unicorn?
DANA BASH: Yeah.

TIM SCOTT: Yes.
DANA BASH: You are.

You're black Republican
from South Carolina.
TIM SCOTT: Yes.

DANA BASH: So you
live this every day.

TIM SCOTT: I definitely
understand it and appreciate
it from a unique perspective.

Both Both senators say
this initiative is not
about politics or legislation.

Have you felt the need
to do more of this

since President Trump has
been in the White House?

JAMES LANKFORD: His rhetoric is
not artful, to say the least.

This started for us a
year and a half ago or so.
I mean, this is not new for us.
It's not new for the nation.

DANA BASH: Still, in
today's political climate,

the idea of figuring out
differences over a warm meal
seems more necessary than ever.
